Operator training simulators in virtual reality environment for process operators: a review
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • S.I. : Virtual Reality, Augmented Reality and Commerce
  • Published: 27 June 2018

Operator training simulators in virtual reality environment for process operators: a review

  • Dipesh S. Patle  ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-7592-54441,2 na1 nAff4,
  • Davide Manca2,
  • Salman Nazir3 &
  • Swapnil Sharma1 

Virtual Reality volume 23, pages293–311(2019)Cite this article

  • 898 Accesses

  • 1 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Given the factors such as safety, profitability, and environmental concerns at stake, operator training is an everlasting and vital process in the process industry. An inevitable need for skilled operators in the chemical industry leads to search for novel and effective training methodologies. Consequently, dynamic simulation techniques have been considered as a tool to educate and train inexperienced personnel as expected by the industry. Traditional training methodologies are hardly sufficient to instruct the operators for seldom-occurring perilous situations. Conventional operator training simulators (OTS) are generally effective, but they lack to give operators the actual feel of the scenarios. Training effectiveness can be enhanced by providing operators with a sense of realism. Therefore, integration of OTS with virtual reality (VR-OTS) certainly comes out to be an alternative. VR-OTS can replicate emergency conditions, accidents, and investigate safety protocols. In this work, we discuss the need for virtual reality (VR) in OTS, merits of VR-OTS, and the role of training assessment methods. Contributions of OTS Authors’ in process industry from year 2000 to mid-2017 are reviewed and discussed extensively. The review shows that VR-OTS provides tangible benefits over its conventional counterparts in terms of improved safety of plant, increased productivity, and environmental protection. Finally, this paper outlines future scopes that the current researcher may consider to focus for the increased and improved VR-OTS usage.

Introduction

The role of operators is now more demanding and crucial than ever before because of an evident surge in the intricacy of modern plants due to the increase in automation, advanced control, and online optimization (Naderpour et al. 2015; Salmon et al. 2009). The operators of modern industrial plants face additional challenges because of the increased complexity (Nazir et al. 2015b). Consequently, this enhances the chances for potential errors that may result in catastrophic accidents. Evidently, from the industrial studies of the 170 largest property damage losses over three decades as reported in 2001 (Yang et al. 2001), 28% of property losses in the hydrocarbon processing industries was due to operational errors or process upsets. Also, the total accumulated value of the 100 largest losses occurred from 1974 to 2013 based on 2013 property damage value was estimated to be more than US$ 34 billion, where upstream (34%), refining (29%), and petrochemical (23%) sectors contributed the most while the gas processing and distribution sectors shared a small fraction of 9 and 5%, respectively (Mannan 2017). Lack of proper training has been identified as one of the primary reasons for industrial accidents (Nazir et al. 2012c). The restructure and adoption of training methods in the process industry have not yet matched the pace of the technological development (Nazir et al. 2015a).

Each year millions of dollars are lost because of accidents, unscheduled shutdowns, or abnormal situations. For example, the notorious Deepwater Horizon oil spill caused an estimated economic loss of US$ 90 billion (Nazir et al. 2014). In addition, safety is of utmost importance especially in those industries dealing with hazardous materials. The incorrect manipulation of process units by the operator(s) was found to be the main source of abnormal situations and potential accidents (Reinach and Viale 2006). Most of the abnormal situations, which arise in a process plant, are less due to the failure of equipment, design, or system and are more due to inappropriate reaction/understanding of the operator who may transform a possible little problem into a serious accident (Cozens et al. 2002). Antonovsky et al. (2014) reported that 45 petroleum industries were surveyed to understand the factors responsible for accidents using HFIT (Human Factor Investigation Tool). They found that the most common reason among all failures was an erroneous interpretation or assumption made by the operator(s). Therefore, it can be concluded that the operators’ understanding/awareness and their accurate actions are essential in ensuring the safety and productivity of industrial plants.

Conventional training methods and operator training simulators are generally effective in training and learning of operations for frequently occurring situations (Nazir et al. 2015b; Brambilla and Manca 2011). The characteristics of OTS are discussed in Patle et al. (2014). However, methods that are more effective need to be explored to handle the seldom-occurring unexpected situations, which may lead to disasters. Accordingly, the researchers have been involved in advancing the training methods for industrial operators in order to improve their performance, reliability, and ability to handle normal, abnormal, and rare situations like start-ups or shutdowns (Kluge 2014; Kluge et al. 2009). The advancement of training methods has led to the development of operator training simulators (OTS). The OTS are designed to act as a repository of plant know-how as relevant operating scenarios can be included into the system and may be replayed for training purposes as and when required (Manca et al. 2013b). The simulator model should be capable of running in real time, with an interface with the distributed control system (DCS) (Cox et al. 2006). DCS is commonly used in computerized control systems of chemical plants with a number of control loops distributed throughout the plant and is installed in a central control room with remote monitoring and supervision features. The advancement of OTS for chemical plants is an important branch of process systems engineering (Zhiyun et al. 2003). Manca et al. (2012b) state that operator training is becoming increasingly important with the rise in automation of industrial plants that require advanced training methods where virtual reality (VR) was discussed.

One of the main problems of standard OTS projects is that they are delivered as a standalone platform (product-oriented paradigm), leaving most of the knowledge needed to actually develop the dynamic model and encapsulate the process and operational knowledge used in the plant design phase out of the package (Nazir and Manca 2015). Usually, as the years go by, delivered OTS platforms are unattended and not updated, which finally ends up with them being used as auxiliary parts for the real operator stations (Toro et al. 2013). Notably, conventional OTS also lack at providing operators with the real feel of scenarios during the training as they rely on 2D representations.

Virtual reality is an important visualization technique that is increasingly applied for plant-safety purposes. The benefits of using immersive virtual environments (IVE) in operators’ training started to emerge during the 90s of last century. However, the easy availability, lesser cost, and new advancements (including augmented virtual reality (AVR), i.e., a virtual view of a physical, real-world environment whose elements are augmented) have made IVE a viable tool for operator training (Passos et al. 2016; Cibulka et al. 2016). IVE allow encountering the related feelings and emotions; those felt in real practice, e.g., the similar anxiety, fears, and concerns. In IVE, the operator during the training session experiences their physical presence within the rendered environment where the operator can move around the virtual equipment without the risk of getting injured, being exposed to heat radiation, or being affected by real accident events as they would happen in on-job training (Aggarwal et al. 2006). In terms of learning benefits, a detailed review by Dalgarno and Lee (2010) exhibits the “learning affordances” of IVE in various contexts. The virtual environment features both a 3D stereoscopic representation of the spatial domain of the plant with background sounds (typically reproduced in high fidelity) to increase the immersivity of the training experience. VR and immersive environments have been used in diverse applications related to training and education such as: engineering applications (e.g., Nazir et al. 2012b; Shang et al. 2009; Fiske and Hill 2010), psychology (e.g., Formosa et al. 2018), and physical education (e.g., Kang and Kang 2018). This prompts the investigation of their use in training process operator’s by incorporating the VR with conventional OTS.

IVE are 3D immersive environments that allow operators to perform tasks and collaborate within a virtual representation of the working station (Manca et al. 2012b). Manca et al. (2012b) developed a plant simulator (PS) that was able to create dynamic, immersive, three-dimensional, fully immersive settings, where the behavioral response could be recorded; it offered a number of assessment and rehabilitation options that were not available with conventional assessment methods (Manca et al. 2012a, 2014). The PS can be considered as a training simulator using IVE augmented by computational software and algorithms to assess the operator/trainee performance in a proper manner. Rose et al. (2005) stated that virtual environments focusing on component cognitive and attention processes were recently developed and validated for spatial abilities, learning and memory, and executive functions. Haller et al. (1999) presented the prototype of VR, which is a VR-based safety training system in a petroleum refinery. It provides an improved technique for personnel safety training and allows users to navigate through parts of the refinery and interact with the environment. This trainer module can communicate with the trainee visualization program, which uses head mounted display and conveys a high degree of immersion. The addition of the AVR feature to IVE may significantly enhance the training level of operators as they can visualize several aspects of the process and even enable the operator to understand and quantify the background information (Shang et al. 2009). Shang et al. (2009) used AVR to train operators under abnormal conditions and provide information about the heat radiated by overheated equipment and accident fires, the thermal load absorbed by the FOP (field operator) as a function of their personal protective devices and exposure times, the concentration of toxic components in a dense/buoyant gas cloud emitted by a damaged unit, the incident overpressure in case of deflagration/detonation with the probability of eardrum and lung ruptures. Li et al. (2002) showed the effectiveness of VR in education by developing a learning-training simulator with virtual functions to safely and efficiently enhance metal cutting education courses in industrial high schools, vocational training schools, and engineering faculties of universities. The survey by Berg and Vance (2017) reported a variety of real-life examples of how VR is being used to support stronger understanding through immersive experiences. In summary, the details and dynamics of the process can be better understood with the help of AVR (Aggarwal et al. 2006; Shang et al. 2009).

This article carries out a detailed review of OTS in virtual reality environments, i.e., VR-OTS, with the purpose of providing an in-depth understanding about training methodologies and benefits of VR/AVR in operator training to stimulate further advancements in OTS development. Key merits of VR-OTS are presented and their tangible benefits are discussed in detail. This article is organized as follows. Section 2 presents a perspective on OTS in VR environments. The application of VR-OTS in industry from 2001 to mid-2017 is discussed in Sect. 3. Tangible benefits offered by VR-OTS is argued in Sect. 4. Contextual discussion on cost versus benefits of VR-OTS in Sect. 5 and role of training assessment methods are reported in Sect. 6. Finally, the article debates on the future scopes of VR-OTS.

Perspective on OTS in VR environments (VR-OTS)

Safety can be improved by testing and validating the operating procedures and control strategies as well as by sharing the operating scenarios between teams (Muravyev and Berutti 2007). Conventionally, OTS are used to enable control room operators (CROP) to understand the process dynamics and test their own capabilities to promptly and correctly react to abnormal situations. Actually, without the possibility for interaction with field operators (FOP), the CROP’s experience becomes limited in a classical OTS training with the risk of performing the wrong actions when the skills gained in the conventional OTS are transferred to the reality (Nazir et al. 2014). The same is the case with dynamic accident simulators, which are useful for quantifying the dynamics of the accident and that convey the rational message of what the problem is and what the consequences are, i.e., explain the dynamics, but not train operators. These dynamic simulators do not allow FOPs moving around in a 3D immersive environment and getting acquainted with all those factors, by acting on the human senses, which influence their performance in reaching the correct mental model of what is happening (Brambilla and Manca 2009, 2011). In summary, conventional 2D OTS do not provide operators with real-life experience and do not intrinsically allow testing and experimenting team dynamics (e.g., coordination, communication, coping with interruptions, leadership, etc.). Virtual environments (VE) with the addition of AVR may significantly enhance the training level of operators as they enable visualizing several hidden aspects of the process and accident. Therefore, the process can be comprehensively understood by the operators with the help of AVR (Nazir et al. 2012c). This improved engineering solution can be based on a fully immersive virtual environment (VE), empowered by 3D audio effects, which enable the trainee(s) to experience the nominal and critical plant conditions, learn process dynamics, and how to control it to prevent accidents and handle emergencies effectively. By doing so, multiple shortcomings such as compromising the production, endangering plant personnel and the surrounding population, contaminating the environment, jeopardizing the relationships with local authorities, increasing insurance premiums can be tackled. Field operators (FOP) learn what are the key process parameters and their effect in terms of characteristic times and response amplitudes, thus increasing their process awareness (Manca et al. 2013a). In addition, the rehearsal of specific events induces the enhancement of the process understanding while testing a number of occurrences that usually do not happen throughout the plant life, and hence cannot be learned and experienced during the job span (Nazir et al. 2012c; Monferini et al. 2010).

Learning in IVE

Most of learning theories are focused on traditional learning methods (e.g., classroom training, simulator training), thus, just relating learning to IVE grounded on or associated with a specific learning theory is not feasible yet. However, based on the principle “learning by doing,” immersive learning—with the use of recent immersive solutions, i.e., HTC Vive or Oculus Rift (which are immersive VR goggles), theoretically provides the following benefits:

  • Complete immersion in the simulated scenario. The immersion is higher than the 3D projectors as field of view, field of regard, and sensory stimulation are greater.

  • Physical involvement by introducing tools like handheld controllers and VR treadmills (however, the presence of the operator’s own body, where one can see and use their own hands in the projection environment, would further benefit the operator).

  • Greater familiarity with the training objective and real-time engagement.

  • Increased mobility and ease of access of training facilities.

  • Greater emphasis on learner control and engagement.

  • A more naturalistic environment provides less gap in learning transfer.

  • Comparative cheaper and efficient training solutions after the initial investment.

  • Potential of introducing objective performance measures (e.g., eye tracker within a headset)

  • Collaboration among distant players/actors/operators working on various units in a process plant.

  • Video recording of the performance in VR which can be reviewed later.

  • Continuous advancement in simulators on account of rapid development of VR tools.

Even though the solutions offered by recent immersive solutions, e.g., Oculus Rift and HTC vive are largely promising, several aspects such as motion or cyber sickness (Howarth and Costello 1997), maximum amount of time that one can be immersed in a training exercise (Hill and Howarth 2000), coordination with other team members (Kanawattanachai and Yoo 2007), etc., need to be investigated and resolved before these solutions can replace existing training simulators. The immersion can be said to be higher in HMDs because of the added benefits offered such as physical mobility, which may be offered when these are used in conjunction with a VR treadmill. The advancement in eye trackers, galvanic skin response, and heart rate variability tools can provide reliable objective performance measurement in an immersive training session (Steptoe et al. 2009). In addition, collecting video records or logging the performance can be simpler in IVE as compared to existing OTS.

Paradigm shift in training methodology: differences between VR-OTS and conventional OTS

Historically, the operator training consisted of one or some of the following:

  • Classroom training: imparting knowledge on plant and process, teaching the fundamentals of a plant, e.g., teaching about its structure and function, and about elementary chemistry and physics.

  • On-job training: training a new operator by an experienced operator (EO) in a face-to-face situation.

  • Training on a simulated plant (e.g., OTS): using the representation of the task to be used by trainees safely practice and gain the operating skill.

In the past, an effective training method was considered a combination of the above methods. However, this assumption is not enough for effectively training the operators as (1) classroom training may be inadequate, (2) on-job training is risky and (3) conventional OTS does not give operators the real feel of actual scenarios. Recent studies show that there has been a paradigm shift in the training methodology. Conventional training methods alone are no longer considered sufficient in training operators for highly automated plants. In addition to training teams on the identification of process units and the execution of routine tasks, there is increasing emphasis on training operators for the recognition and recovery of anomalies and malfunctions by empowering their capability of anticipating events, especially when they might lead to accidents (Manca et al. 2013a).

As reported by Patle et al. (2014), the graphical front-ends of large-scale operator training simulators consist of hundreds of thousands of lines of code. The development of training simulators using procedural code is historically expensive, difficult to update, and ultimately unmanageable due to the increased and continuous demand of graphical complexity. Therefore, it was suggested to develop the graphical interfaces using object-oriented programming methods. Patle et al. (2014) also mentioned that a real-time dynamic simulator should allow the simulation of existing plants as well as the newly introduced processes according to plant demands. This requires the simulator to be designed in a modular fashion, where different flow sheets are built by combining the unit operation modules and new modules can be introduced with minimal changes. Table 1 presents a comparison of different training methodologies.

Developing a VR-OTS is a truly multidisciplinary approach. The development of the VR-OTS for training purposes requires the understanding and knowledge of several fields: development of the dynamic model of process, numerical solver, real-time programming of digital equipment, programming tools, man–machine interface, immersive environments, pedagogy theories, subject matter experts, etc. This invariably requires that several experts accomplish the development of VR-OTS, each of them having specialized knowledge of some of the fields involved while exhibiting a global understanding of the ultimate goal. For instance, the pool fire simulation because of a leakage of butane after a flange rupture, as depicted in Fig. 1a, b, would require the expertise from all of the above. Clearly, such a realistic visualization of the probable real-time accidents during training would impart enough confidence in the trainees so that they can respond promptly should such an event occur in future.

How much VR-OTS are more effective than conventional OTS?

Using VR with conventional OTS provides a comprehensive training of operators as they experience a near-real situation. Scenarios like process start-ups, emergency shutdowns, abnormal situations, equipment malfunctions, and infrequently occurring accidents can be simulated virtually in a 3D immersive environment and replayed as and when required by means of the VR-OTS solution. This thus enhances the situation-handling capability of the operators. In short, such a feature enables effective training to take place in a safe and controlled environment.

Ahmad et al. (2016) developed an OTS using Aspen OTS Framework for a homogeneously catalyzed biodiesel production process. Several malfunction scenarios were tested on the developed OTS, where the process was shown in 2D (without VR). Figure 2a depicts the snapshot of the developed OTS showing just a distillation column with all controller faceplates. Noticeably, Fig. 2a lacks the details of auxiliaries such as pumps, valves, holes, flanges, switches, and measuring instruments. Another striking point is that Fig. 2a depicts the condenser at the top of the column. However, a condenser is usually mounted on the ground for both stability and maintenance issues. Figure 2b shows an immersive 3D representation of a distillation column along with its auxiliary instruments. Clearly, this representation conveys a real feel as compared to the 2D distillation column shown in Fig. 2a.

By incorporating this immersive environment to the conventional OTS, FOPs can go through frequently occurring scenarios, whereas CROPs can come into contact with the human–machine interface and simulate the interaction with the distributed control system (DCS) as well as with FOPs for any in-the-field feedback and at-the-field manual operation by means of suitable remote communication devices such as walkie-talkies (Nazir et al. 2012c; Nazir and Manca 2015). This allows testing and assessing the FOP-CROP decision-making procedures and illustrates the effectiveness of immersive environments in training activities. The next section discusses the application of VR to operators training.

VR-OTS in the chemical process industry

Process simulators are widely used in chemical and petrochemical industries for operator training, plant design, and optimization. A process model allows achieving an accurate reproduction of plant behavior during all operating situations, namely transient state and steady state, based on reliable physical phenomena, kinetics, mass, heat and momentum transfer, and thermodynamics. The simulation environment consists of basic unit operations such as pumps, valves, reactors, and vessels, combined with a user-specified property package, to calculate the thermodynamic and physical properties such as enthalpy, density, and compositions (Siminovich and Joao 2014). Dynamic simulation based on OTS has been in use in chemical and petrochemicals for some time. Lack of realism and fidelity restricts these methods from optimal training and being understood by operators (Nazir et al. 2013a). The training of operators in IVE, comprising both VR and AVR, can result in better understanding, and hence better performance of industrial operators in case of (ab)normal operating conditions (Nazir et al. 2012b). To respond efficiently to an abnormal situation, operators should demonstrate problem-detection skills and rapid re-planning strategies. Mental workload and attention are strongly interlinked with each other (Tsang and Vidulich 2006). Nazir et al. (2013a) discussed in detail the concept and benefits of employing virtual reality for training operators in the process industry to deal with the aforementioned challenges. This enables effective training to take place in a safe and controlled environment (Shang et al. 2009). Fiske and Hill (2010) highlighted the benefits of using a detailed IVE for training operators of both the process and the energy industries. Bell and Fogler (1996) and Bell and Fogler (2004) reported the application of VR in engineering education in three broad project areas: virtual chemical plants, virtual laboratory accidents, and a virtual University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) campus. Wasfy and Noor (2001) discussed how to represent the results of CFD simulations in VE. In particular, they showed that it is possible to represent abstract concepts as the flow around obstacles with different solutions, e.g., stream objects (lines, ribbons, and volumes), colored surfaces, elevation surfaces, and global or local iso-surfaces. The intrinsic limitations of conventional OTS must be overcome by means of a dedicated design and implementation of simulation tools capable to introduce the stressors inside the training procedure so to accustom the operators and make them ready for real operations (Manca et al. 2016). Manca et al. (2013a) pointed out the interactions between the process and the accident outcomes as well as the associated feedback loop, i.e., how the process influences both the release rate and conditions, which on their turn influence the accident outcomes (i.e., the flame dimensions and radiative heat flux in this case) and the process itself. They showed how a plant simulator (PS) can be used effectively for hazard identification and assessment, consequence analysis, and education and training of both field and control room operators. Some of the applications of OTS in virtual environment are mentioned below. Table 2 details the highlights of the VR-based OTS for chemical processes mentioned below.

Three-dimensional interactive virtual chemical laboratory

Lily et al. (2008) proposed a three-dimensional interactive virtual chemical laboratory framework based on the constructivist learning theory, three-dimensional modeling, and scene interactive technology of Virtual Reality Modeling Language (VRML). In addition, they developed a real experimental environment and implemented the complex human–machine interaction in chemistry to make the learners get the senses of realism and immersion.

Chemical process simulation system

Cheng-jun et al. (2010) built a distributed interactive chemical process simulation system with the abilities of chemical process training, monitoring, testing, and replying. Data-driven simulation framework was proposed, and some related key technologies such as modeling and chemical process path calculation were discussed by the authors.

Die-casting factory

Based on the virtual reality approach, Manesh et al. (2011) analyzed a real industrial plant, a medium sized die-casting factory (Fig. 3). They concluded that VR has better interaction effects for representing manufacturing systems in operation than other standard graphical user interfaces. Figure 3 depicts the overall layout of the die-casting factory. However, it does not provide any operational data.

Gas leaks in the OIL company

Plant simulator of the specific plant section was created, and experiments were performed with real operators in virtual environment by Colombo et al. (2011).

Distillation columns

Nazir et al. (2012c) discussed the application of IVE by taking distillation columns as a case study. They reported that the immersivity of the IVE, coupled to the high degree of detail of the rendering, allows the operators becoming aware of the process units and understanding their features and geometrical layout for future possible interventions in case of start-ups, shutdowns, grade changes, malfunctions, abnormal situations, alarms, and accident events. One such study emphasizes on deepening the use of IVE by analyzing two training methods within the PS solution for normal operating conditions.

Damage of a pipe in C3/C4 distillation unit

Colombo et al. (2014) created an accident scenario that involved an excavator working in proximity of the C3/C4 distillation unit that accidentally hits a pipe carrying a stream of pressurized liquid butane (C4). The outcome was a broken flange of the C4 pipe with a resultant leakage and the formation of a spreading pool on the ground and ultimately fire.

Hydrodealkylation (HDA) of toluene to benzene

Events such as process start-ups, shutdowns, abnormal situations, near-misses, malfunctions, and accidents can be simulated virtually in a 3D immersive environment and replayed a number of times, thus enhancing the degree of knowledge and experience of operators (Manca et al. 2013a).

Polymerization process (catalyst injector switch)

Manca et al. (2014) developed an OTS for a real polymerization process that produces one of the most important and diffused polymers. The catalyst injector switch (CIS) procedure comprised of 32 actions.

Oil and gas rigs

Kozlak et al. (2014) show another VR-based system for oil and gas rig, where an operator is running a machine. This clearly illustrates significance of the VR in providing effective training by providing the sense of realism.

Ethylene process

Luo et al. (2015) developed a virtual factory for ethylene plant, where a realistic 3D model of the plant was implemented and interacted with a dynamic and control simulator. Figure 4 shows the VR model of an ethylene factory, where a complete plant is displayed.

Polymerization process (production of propylene)

Nazir and Manca (2015) developed a simulator, i.e., PS, in VR that could be used not only for OTS purposes but also for decision-making and process/procedure improvement. Even PS was able to couple process details, evolution of accident, and record the actions and errors committed by the operator.

Ahmad et al. (2016) developed an OTS for a homogeneously catalyzed biodiesel production process. Various malfunction scenarios such as utility failure, pump failure, valve malfunction, fire in a flash, reflux failure, and interlock were tested on the developed OTS, where the process is shown in 2D. Table 2 presents the applications of VR-OTS in chemical processes from year 2000 to mid-2017, which lists the highlights of the reported works and the applied training environment. This table denotes that IVE have been successfully applied for OTS development in various fields in recent years, and that there is an increased interest in using IVE in operators’ training.

Although conventional OTS has found its widespread applications in diverse fields such as oil and gas, petrochemical and power and energy, aviation, and nuclear domains in the last few decades, it was only in recent years that inclusion of virtual environments was given special attention owing to the drawbacks of conventional OTS. In general, OTS are used in the industries where the risks associated with their operation are high. Inclusion of virtual reality is an aspect that requires a careful assessment due to its (much) higher cost of development. Training outside the direct working environment without VR provides limited realistic opportunities; consequently, it is far from achieving what is desired in a tensed and demanding working environment. VR training systems can be cost-effective alternatives to creating full-scale real-life training scenarios for the plants involving higher risks related to cost and human life. Another benefit of such systems is that they can be designed to be multilingual, and trainees can be taught in their language of choice. In addition, it offers a platform to create a wide variety of scenarios, including the ones that occur rarely. Trainers can review trainees’ records from an extensive database, compare results and generate graphs of performance of individuals or groups to identify the weak areas and restructure the training accordingly. General advantages of training with OTS are discussed in detail by Patle et al. (2014). How incorporation of OTS in immersive environments is effective in operator training is discussed in Sect. 2.3 of this manuscript. Colombo et al. (2014) reported that use of IVE in the process industry, for training and decision-making purposes, remarkably improves the performance of FOPs in several aspects, e.g., response time and accuracy of actions. The benefits associated with the use of VR in training methods are discussed by Nazir et al. (2012c).

Contextual discussion on cost versus benefits of VR-OTS

Usually, an OTS is installed at the production site even before the commissioning of the real plant, to train the operators and engineers before the actual plant start-up. OTS is also valuable and beneficial for operator training for both CROP as well as FOP when installed afterward. Studies have shown that an OTS gives operators the equivalent of six years of on-the-job training, especially in emergency scenarios (Manca 2017). A study by the American Petroleum Institute (API) identified more than US$ 350,000 per year of benefits when upgrading the skills of an average operator trained on a regular basis by means of an OTS (Manca 2017). Ayral and Jonge (2016) estimated the total annualized benefits of an OTS for a 100,000 bpd refinery being US$ 4.9 million. Erroneous actions of operators may also lead to the shutdown of the plant that may cost millions of dollars a day. For instance, Colombo et al. (2011) reported the shutdown costs for a European oil refinery being 10 million Euro per day.

Alongside a considerable economic investment, the added-value and return-on-investment are significant. One of the major benefits of the OTS is the ability to allow systematizing the knowledge while keeping the experience, expertise, and skills inside the plant. Associating conventional OTS with VR provide several benefits as discussed in earlier sections. However, inclusion of VR increases the cost of development. Therefore, its cost-effectiveness should be measured in terms of additional cost to additional benefits offered on a case-to-case basis. Additional cost includes the expenditures for including VR with conventional OTS such as VR tools/immersive solutions, whereas additional benefits are increased skill development, improved safety, reduced downtime, and environmental protection. Converting conventional OTS to VR-OTS requires additional tools such as HTC Vive or Oculus Rift; however, other components such as process model and emulated control system remain the same. In general, large-scale industries/processes with high risk factors would find beneficial to invest more on VR as compared to small-scale low-risk industries. With the advent of technology, the cost to benefit ratio for OTS continues to improve. This becomes even more beneficial considering safety and environmental regulations imposed by governing bodies. Models developed for training can be used for multiple applications such as expanded engineering applications, control studies, and plant design. In addition, real plant data can be used to initialize the OTS to previous plant conditions for training. Additional data on training benefits, cost savings, and improved plant performance criteria from OTS users may come handy to evaluate and quantify the specific additional benefits that can be obtained from a VR-OTS. Additionally, increased usage of VR-OTS in industries is likely to bring down the investment and improve the benefits. Unfortunately, there is not much quantitative data available in the open literature to show the cost of VR-OTS development as well as the quantitative monitory benefits.

Role of training assessment methods

Another important factor in OTS training is the assessment methods, which should be given significant attention. Before training the operators, the goal of training for a particular plant must be identified as the requirement may be plant specific depending on factors like type of process, level of automation, etc. Training methodology should be designed to assess the operators’ capability after they have undergone the training so that the management is confident about their workers.

In addition to the goal of training, the set of responsibilities that would be assigned to the operator should be considered while designing a training session. To run a plant smoothly, reduce plant downtime and avoid hazards that will affect plant, personnel, and the environment, it is crucial to have a clear understanding of the sort of operators’ skills that are desired. It is also important to train the operators on how to interact with the process through the DCS or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) human–machine interface (HMI). Defining and developing the performance indexes for the process operators is crucial in any training assessment.

Lee et al. (2000) proposed a method for evaluating the operators’ plant manipulation capability by using an OTS. They developed an algorithm, which was termed as task evaluation algorithm (TEA), to analyze and evaluate the operators’ training results automatically after they finalized the training session by using the graphical user interface (GUI) emulation of DCS. TEA included two main modules, namely sequence evaluation module (SEM) and quantity evaluation module (QEM). The former indicated whether the operator follows the correct operating sequence, while the latter reports the deviation of each operator’s task from the standard operating procedure. TEA was shown to be efficient and effective in analyzing the operator’s skills.

Nazir et al. (2013a) reported different training methodologies and concluded that the process operations were significantly improved with respect to the conventional ones adopted to train FOPs (field operators). The advantages and usefulness of IVE implemented in the PS training solution were tested and shown by Nazir et al. (2012a) and Colombo et al. (2013). Those experiments simulated an accident event and compared two different training methods, i.e., a PowerPoint presentation versus PS (with IVE). Many traditional assessment methods are prone to the subjectivity of the trainer that may make the training assessment unreliable (Colombo et al. 2014); hence, an automated approach was suggested where some experienced assessors would contribute in defining an algorithm for the operators’ assessment, which would evaluate the operator performance automatically, thus avoiding any subjectivity related to the assessor. Few more articles (Patle et al. 2014; Aggarwal et al. 2006; Manca et al. 2012b; Nazir et al. 2013a; Park et al. 2004) also focused on the training and training assessment.

In addition, it is crucial to maintain updated the OTS as reported in Patle et al. (2014). They argued that it may become just a checkoff requirement rather than being a learning tool, if not maintained well. Indeed, poorly maintained OTS may be worse than not having it because operators may falsely think that they know what is going to happen that is far from reality, and any such OTS outcome would provide the management with false indications.

Concluding remarks and future directions

In this review, we presented and discussed the needs and merits of OTS combined with virtual reality. A paradigm shift in training methodologies over the recent period was presented. Contributions on VR-OTS in chemical industry from year 2000 to mid-2017 were reviewed and discussed for their merits. We found that it is invariably reported that the inclusion of VR makes the training more effective. In conclusion, VR-OTSs can provide tangible benefits over their conventional counterparts, as they are able to give the operators a sense of realism, thereby increasing their situation awareness. Contextual discussion of cost to benefit ratio was also presented to facilitate a deeper understanding about the application of VR-OTS. In addition, the article covered the role of training assessment methods. Addition of VR in conventional OTS or new OTS with both VR and AVR features can provide better operator training by allowing operators to have real-life simulated experience. Broadly, the benefits can be obtained in terms of safe operation of the plant, higher productivity, lesser number of accidents, and lesser damage to the environment.

Maintaining and/or updating VR-OTS to meet the ever-changing demands is one of the major challenges. This problem is likely to be more significant in case of VR-OTS than in case of conventional OTS as it requires VR/AVR experts and additional cost. To face such challenges, (1) VR-OTS should be developed with the plant simulation feature in a modular fashion, (2) it is crucial to develop simulation tools that are more generic in nature and user-friendly, and (3) OTS development being a multidisciplinary task (i.e., the coordination among simulator developers, process engineers, and VR/AVR experts) in performing studies and further implementing the models is of paramount value. The development of easy-to-use and inexpensive tools for VR inclusion is important as it can bring down the cost of VR-OTS, yielding increased use of VR-OTS in industry for operators’ training. This work encourages other researchers to ponder the benefits of VR in operator training and hopefully conduct experiments aimed at identifying long-term learning curves based on VR and supported by OTS.
